data.text: Maps
A map is a drawing made to show some area of the Earth.
A physical map shows hills, mountains, rivers, and other landforms.
A political map shows towns, cities, and borders between states and countries.
A relief map shows the height of hills and mountains.
North, south, east, and west are called compass directions on a map.
A grid of vertical and horizontal lines drawn over a map makes it easier to find a place on the map.
The vertical lines drawn from north to south, passing through the North and South Poles are called meridians of longitude.
The horizontal lines drawn parallel to the equator from east to west are called parallels of latitude.
The equator is the line of latitude that divides the Earth into the northern hemisphere and southern hemisphere.
The 0° meridian is called the Prime Meridian. It passes through a place called Greenwich, near London in England.
The 180° meridian is the International Date Line. It lies exactly opposite the Prime Meridian.
To find a place on a map, we find its grid reference. Colours, symbols, and patterns help us to find things more easily on a map.
Each map has a key that tells us what the symbols and colours used on the map mean.
Each map has a scale that helps us to calculate the actual distance between two places.
